hawaiian_text: Noho ihola i laila, mahi ‘ai, ‘elua āna mau māla  ‘uala lō‘ihi e waiho nei ā hiki i kēia lā, a ua kapa ‘ia  ka inoa o ia mau māla, ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o ā hiki i  kēia lā. A o‘o ka ‘uala, ‘ōlelo ‘o Puali‘i i kāna ‘ōlelo   ho‘ohiki, “Aia ā kālua ke po‘o o ka ulua me ka ‘uala,  a ‘ai ‘o Puali‘i, a laila, noa, ‘ai kāna wahine, Pōka‘ī a  me nā mea ‘ē a‘e. No laila, iho akula ‘o Puali‘i i kai  o Honouliuli e lawai‘a i i‘a ‘ai pū me ka ‘uala.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_translation: Stay here, work for food, two rows of taro fields are left behind in this place, and the name of these fields is called "Namakaokapāo‘o" in this place. And the taro, the speech of Puali‘i in his speech, "Here is the chief of the taro and the speech, the food of Puali‘i, and then, the food of his wife, Pōka‘ī, and the other things. Therefore, Puali‘i went to the sea of Honouliuli to fish for food with the taro."
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_commentary:
• [Allegorical interpretation of the passage]  
  – The text reflects a transition from traditional Hawaiian agricultural practices to maritime activities, symbolizing the shift from sustenance-based to trade-oriented livelihoods during the post-contact era. The "two rows of taro fields" (māla ‘uala) may represent the sacred connection between land, food, and identity, while the act of leaving them behind (e waiho nei) suggests disruption or loss due to external forces.  
  – The name "Puali‘i" (pau + li‘i) could allegorically signify "the one who completes the task" or "the one who is left behind," hinting at a figure navigating between tradition and change. The "sea of Honouliuli" (kai o Honouliuli) might symbolize the Pacific as a space of exploration and transformation, contrasting with the grounded, ancestral ties of taro.  

• [Analysis of character names and symbolism]  
  – **Puali‘i**: "Pau" (to finish, complete) + "li‘i" (to leave, to be left behind). This name may symbolize a leader or figure who embodies the tension between concluding old practices and being displaced by new ones.  
  – **Namakaokapāo‘o**: "Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o" (the sea of the chief’s pāo‘o, a term for a sacred staff or symbol of authority). The name ties the land to the ocean, suggesting a sacred relationship between the fields and the sea, as taro (‘uala) is both a staple crop and a symbol of human origin in Hawaiian cosmology.  
  – **Pōka‘ī**: "Pō" (night) + "ka‘ī" (to be left behind). This name may represent the unseen or the hidden, reflecting the idea of sustenance derived from the ocean’s depths, which were often considered sacred and mysterious.  

• [Historical and cultural context]  
  – The reference to "two rows of taro fields" (māla ‘uala) connects to the *‘Ai Kapu* era (pre-1819), where taro was a sacred plant tied to the *kānaka* (people) as descendants of Hāloa (taro), emphasizing agricultural interdependence with spiritual life (Kamakani, 1992).  
  – The abandonment of *‘Ai Kapu* in 1819, following Kamehameha I’s death, marks a cultural rupture, mirrored here by the act of leaving the fields behind. The narrative may critique this shift, framing it as a loss of ancestral knowledge.  
  – The mention of fishing ("e lawai‘a i i‘a") and the ocean ("kai") reflects the post-1820 missionary influence, where Western practices introduced new methods of resource exploitation, contrasting with traditional *lo‘i* (taro fields) as sites of communal stewardship.  

• [Symbolism of duality and transformation]  
  – The "two rows" (māla ‘uala) may symbolize the *mo‘o* (duality) in Hawaiian cosmology, representing balance between land and sea, or the physical and spiritual realms.  
  – Puali‘i’s journey to the sea could allegorically depict the *mālama ʻāina* (caring for the land) ethos, where survival depends on adapting to environmental and cultural changes, yet risks losing ancestral ties.  

• [Social commentary and critique]  
  – The passage critiques the erosion of traditional food systems, as taro fields (symbolizing *kuleana* [responsibility] and *ʻāina* [land]) are replaced by fishing, reflecting the impact of colonialism on Hawaiian subsistence practices.  
  – The name "Nāmakaokapāo‘o" (sea of the chief’s staff) may allude to the loss of *māla* as sacred spaces, replaced by commodification of resources under foreign influence.

reference_translation: They lived there and farmed, and Puali‘i had two  long sweet potato patches that remain until today,  and the patches were given the name,   Nāmakaokapāo‘o until today. When the sweet  potatoes were mature, Puali‘i said made a  promise, saying, “I’ll cook the head of an ulua fish  in the imu along with some sweet potatoes. When  Puali‘i eats, then the food will be made free for his  woman, Pōka‘ī, and anyone else.” So, Puali‘i went  down to the shore of Honouliuli to fish for a catch  to eat with sweet potatoes.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 4:**• Pua-li‘i is a farmer with 2 long sweet potato patches  that lasted until the publication of this story. The  name of this sweet potato garden was known as *Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o*, the name of Pō-ka-‘ī’s son, and  victorious hero of the story;  • When the sweet potatoes were ready for harvest,  Pua-li‘i said that when he eats ulua fish with sweet  potatoes, cooked in the imu. The food would then be  made free for others, particularly Pō-ka-‘ī and Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o after he eats.  – The emphasis on Pua-li‘i, a male and head of the  family, eating, with his woman and child being  allowed to eat separately after he was done, is a  custom of ‘Ai Kapu culture;  • Having announced the eating routine/schedule, Pua li‘i then went to Hono-uliuli (dark bay) to fish for  ulua.  – The choice of ulua to eat with the ‘uala (sweet  potato) is likely due to the similarity in the   pronunciation of the two words, signifying ʻwhat is  above, so below,’ an old and recurring esoteric  feature of Hawaiian prosidy and culture, with a  lesson that there should always be balance in life  and in human practices (above-below; left-right;  male-female). This is the essence of ʻpono’;
